Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Can Data Mining and Crowd Sourcing Revolutionize the Study of Scientific Peer Review? Generating a National, Open Depository of Grant Review Outcomes from Federal Agencies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
One major barrier to research on peer review is the inaccessibility of data. Federal agencies are required to protect the identities of reviewers and applicants, which makes sharing data challenging, and prevents agencies from capitalizing on the opportunity to improve their systems with the help of the scientific community. This project addresses this problem with a novel automated program that collects peer review outcomes, such as grant application critiques and scores, directly from applicants, and de-identifies and stores them in a large repository that the scientific community can access. More intensive study and refinement of federal agencies' review processes will help to inform federal policies to ensure that U.S. tax dollars are allocated in ways that yield the broadest benefit. Conducting this work will also help broaden participation in science because it has high potential to illuminate reasons why individuals from historically underrepresented groups face disadvantage in peer review processes.

Beginning with the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the largest federal funder of biomedical research, this project's automated data collection program uses web crawlers to identify Principal Investigators (PIs) and their email addresses from NIH's public access database, RePORTER; the program then sends PIs email invitations to donate their review materials (i.e., critiques and scores), which are de-identified and placed in a protected database (with the option to "opt-out" for all PIs). The program asks participating PIs to provide demographic information, and merges demographic and de-identified review outcome information into datasets that can be used for data and text analysis. This automated program can be adapted to collect review outcomes from unfunded applications, as well as from other federal funding agencies, by targeting broader email lists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The first major outcome of this EAGER award is a validated computer program that identifies Principal Investigators’ (PIs’) listed on NIH’s public access database and their email addresses and sends them invitations to donate their application review outcomes (i.e., scores and critiques) for analysis. This program also invites PIs to donate their demographic information and identifies PIs’ productivity information from freely available online sources (e.g., h-index, NIH RCR). The second major outcome is a set of computer programs that transfer critiques and scores into de-identified datasets, merged with demographic and productivity information, for a broad range of text- and data-analyses.

 

The Broader Impacts of this project are that it allows greater access and more intensive study of federal agencies’ review processes, which will help ensure that U.S. tax dollars are allocated in ways that bring the broadest benefit to society. With greater access of data, this project makes possible much needed research focused on identifying and mitigating sources of bias and improving reliability among reviewers in peer review systems. Conducting this work has long-term potential to help broaden participation in the scientific workforce, because individuals from historically underrepresented groups (e.g., women, racial/ethnic minorities) appear to face disadvantage in review processes, which precludes their ability to persist and advance in science, technology, engineering, mathematics, and medical (STEMM) careers. Thus, analysis of data from this project will help to illuminate targets for intervention that may help “level the playing field” and ensure minority scientists have equal opportunity to succeed in research careers.

 

The Intellectual Merit of this project lies in its ability to help NSF fulfill its mission to advance scientific knowledge and ensure the health of the U.S. scientific enterprise with an automated novel method for collecting peer review outcomes from federal funding agencies. With increased access to peer review outcomes, the scientific community will have the opportunity to help agencies evaluate their review processes, ensure they target the best science, and reduce the influence of unintentional bias.
